author: Rose Powell
title: Why pork prices matter for China's central bank
text:
Pork is a staple food in China that analysts say may have a rating in the consumer price index as high as 3 per cent.
Could the skyrocketing pork price dampen Beijing's enthusiasm for more monetary easing to stimulate the country's slowing economy?
Pork prices have been rising in China for more than a year, with the Chinese Ministry of Commerce reporting on Sunday that the meat is fetching 16.7 per cent more than it did 12 months ago.
We expect risks to CPI inflation to remain balanced in the coming months.
Julia Wang, HSBC This was the main factor behind July's rise in China's consumer price index to 1.6 per cent, up 0.2 percentage points from June, despite sluggish growth in the cost of non-food items.
Pork is so popular that it accounts for an estimated 3 per cent of the basket of goods and services used to calculate the country's CPI.
The sharp rise – mainly due to a supply crunch – is causing concern that it could slow action taken by Beijing to boost the struggling economy, the slowdown of which is wreaking havoc on Australian key exports such as iron ore and copper.
"The fear of a further slowdown in China's economy, together with slower global growth and a stronger US dollar, has sent commodity prices plummeting since 2014," Hong Kong-based ANZ researcher Li-Gang Liu said.
However, the ANZ researchers said they didn't believe a rising CPI will materially influence Beijing's policy for long as the inflation spike was likely to be short-lived.
​The People's Bank of China has a range of policy options, including lowering official interest rates or banks' reserve requirement ratios, to stimulate the economy.
HSBC Greater China economist Julia Wang agreed that the spike in pork prices was unlikely to derail further monetary easing by the People's Bank of China, considering persistent weak domestic demand and the fragile economic recovery.
"We expect risks to CPI inflation to remain balanced in the coming months, which should leave ample room for further policy easing," Ms Wang said.
"We forecast further monetary and fiscal easing measures in the coming months, including another 25 basis points policy rate cut and 100 basis points reserve ratio cut in the third quarter of 2015."
In a sign that deflation remains more of a concern than spiralling prices, the producer price index dropped sharply and is likely to win out over the pork-powered CPI inflation in government priorities.
The producer-price index has been dropping steadily for more than four years. In June, it fell 5.4 per cent from a year earlier.
The drop, which exceeded estimates for a 5 per cent decrease, extended declines to 41 straight months.
